comments.commentBody: When will Trump resign?
Looking for a joke with a microscope.
Will no one rid me of this turbulent priest?”
It all makes sense now. No wonder Trump kept talking about a "rigged election", he was projecting his own duplicity onto the other candidate. Oh America, what hast thou done unto thyself?
Since Trump, authoritarian regimes like the U.S. and Israel are ascendant.

replies.commentBody: Thank you. That is a great comment. Telling that it has less than 10 upvotes.

The intelligence agencies have never provided any forensics, signals intelligence or other proof to this "assessment," and without it, I do not trust their public analysis. Anyone can use the Russian hacker tools referred to in the public report, and identifying a TOR exit node -- without pinning down the actual internet address -- is not conclusive. And you mention 17 agencies? This includes the Coast Guard? Gimme a break. This is a Capper special -- the same guy who lied to us about NSA spying, and misinformed Obama re the ISIS threat.

Interference? All the hack did was disclose authentic campaign emails that revealed DNC unfairness to Bernie, and John Podesta's arrogance.

Your source, The Times itself, has confirmed repeatedly that there is no evidence of collusion between Trump campaign and Russia re the hack:

Intelligence officials have said in interviews over the last six weeks that apparent connections between some of Mr. Trump’s aides and Moscow originally compelled them to open a broad investigation into possible links between the Russian government and the Republican presidential candidate. Still, they have said that Mr. Trump himself has not become a target. And no evidence has emerged that would link him or anyone else in his business or political circle directly to Russia’s election operations.

How gullible you are!

Rita -
Gullible is in the eyes of the beholder. Ignoring the intelligence agencies who are specialists in international espionage and actions and agreed upon the Russian interference is kind of silly.

There are many sources now besides the New York Times including the Washington Post, Newsweek and others. The Russian expert from the UK is one of the most respected figures in the field. Investigations are not concluded.

And the intelligence agencies include: DIA, NGIA, NRO, NSA, ISC, ONI, 25th Air Force, Marine Corps Intelligence, Coast Guard Intelligence, OIA, CIA, Bureau of Intelligence and Research, Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, Office of National Security Intelligence (DEA), Intelligence Branch (FBI), Office of Intelligence and Counterintelligence, etc. These are all official agencies that are under the Director of National Intelligence.

Insults are cheap, by the way. Please in the future cite your own sources instead of insulting another commenter.

comments.commentBody:
Wow. Nothing new here re Russia/Trump interaction: after 8 months of intensive investigation, still no proof of collusion by the Trump campaign to hack the Democrats. (Remember, that is the underlying allegation.)

But here is what is new and exciting: As reported as fact by The Times, the Obama administration and elements of the CIA and NSA have engaged in a criminal conspiracy against Trump, and enlisted The Times and other MSM as its wingmen!

This opens up an exciting new avenue of investigation for The Times, other "investigative" media, and most saliently -- FBI counterintelligence. As confirmed by The Times, senior officials in the Obama administration teamed up with high-level CIA and NSA spooks to destabilize and destroy the democratically elected government of Donald Trump. They underclassified top secret information, spread it around the bureaucracy, and leaked classified information to pliant reporters. All illegal. Truly a classic CIA op -- in the mold of similar covert operations against Vietnam, Nicaragua and more recently, Ukraine. Remember, these folks were dead wrong about Iraqi WMD and ISIS, & spied on the American people.)

Let's get to the bottom of this! Tell us your sources. What was provided to you? How did you ascertain the motives of the leakers? Did Obama authorize this operation?

Finally, did any D leaders, or anyone from the Hilary Clinton campaign participate in this destablization operation? Adam Schiff, perhaps?

comments.commentBody: As I see the leaks trickle out incessantly - I have the feeling that someone, who is/was in a very powerful position, very smart, knows how things work in government, intelligence agencies and the Congress, a patriot, has loyalists working for him/her, knows a lot of details on these alleged ties between Russia and the Trump camp - is directing this whole thing (holding the government to account), with the intention to bring the truth out to the American people. Who could this be?

"Can stop on a dime and give you nine cents change."

The lad went from implying Trump was an idiot for even suggesting the possibility of Russian hacking...to rushing "to preserve intelligence of Russian election hacking" in one fell swoop. He was nothing if not agile.

comments.commentBody:
Didn't the Obama administration investigate Russian involvement in the election and report that there was no collusion between the Russians and the Trump campaign? Pretty sure they did. Now it turns out the Obama team is leaking information to contradict the conclusion of the investigation.

These are despicable people.

We don't need any fictitious Russian sleeper cells like the "Americans" working within our country, when we have factual "friends" of Russia like Flynn and Sessions operating within this country.  Poor President Reagan, how many times must he be turning in his grave.

We have been told that there was a meeting before the election among the intelligence agency heads and Congressional leaders. In this meeting the evidence of Russian interference in the election was laid out. The Administration wanted a bipartisan statement from Congress warning about the Russian interference but McConnell refused, saying he would call it partisan attacks if the evidence were released.
James Comey participated in those meetings. Yet he still went on to smear Hillary Clinton with false innuendo while protecting the more serious charges against Trump's campaign. Presumably President Obama knew about all of this. Yet he let Comey corrupt the FBI. One can't help but draw the conclusion that President Obama was more concerned about his personal reputation for fairness than he was about seeing that the agencies, then under his control, guaranteed the fairness of the American electoral process.
The problem we might have getting to the bottom of all of this is that there was widespread agreement in the Executive and Legislative Branches to cover up the dangerous connections of the Trump people. While not rising to the level of possible treason committed by the Trump people, the behavior of the last Congress and the Obama administration is still very worrisome

I have been saying for some time that a very simple and plausible reason why Trump keeps saying the press are "liars" is because there's some really shady stuff out there about him -- and his only hope of keeping the presidency is to convince America not to believe the press when the truth comes out.
It is a simple explanation for his hammering about the "lying press" -- which ramped up during the Flynn-Russia investigation but started at a suspiciously early point in his campaign.
You know who else said the press were all liars? Nixon in 1972.

replies.commentBody: Speaking of the IRS, when is your draft dodging electoral president going to release his taxes?
Nixon tried to have the FTC revoke the Washington Post's ownership of several TV stations to bankrupt it.  See "The Best and The Brightest" by David Halberstam

comments.commentBody: Let's just hope this administration doesn't do something unprecedented and sic a powerful government agency like the IRS on its political opponents. That would be hard to imagine and the media outcry would certainly be extreme!

I am thankful for the independent investigations by some of our allies (the British and the Dutch).  It's difficult to know, at this point, whether any of our intelligence agents have been compromised or otherwise not forthcoming with intel (e.g., Flynn, Comey and some members of intelligence committees in Congress).  How ironic that the British may be a rescuer of our democracy.
Why not just appoint the Russian Ambassador as the Secretary for Russian-American Affairs in Trump's cabinet?  Would certainly seem to make things simpler.

comments.commentBody:
How unusual is it for a member of Congress to have dealings with the Russian ambassador? The following from today's Washington Post suggests that it is no ordinary occurrence:

"The Washington Post contacted all 26 members of the 2016 Senate Armed Services Committee to see whether any lawmakers besides Sessions met with Kislyak in 2016. Of the 20 lawmakers who responded, every senator, including Chairman John McCain (R-Ariz.), said they did not meet with the Russian ambassador last year."

Unless we are missing something it seems odd that Sessions would be meeting with Kislyak. Seems even stranger that Sessions would not think to mention it during confirmation hearings, especially given that Russia meddling in the election was (and is) of such evident concern.

The DNC brushed aside warnings from the FBI that its computer networks were breached by hackers linked to the Russian govt. Their tech worker did little or nothing to heed the FBI's warning. How come they took it seriously after they lost the elections? If the hacking could have been prevented, was deliberately allowed? This angle is also worth investigating. One could be accused of mischief if he allows and even keeps data on what he could prevent in other to use it as a tool to discredit an opponent.

In written questions, Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) asked, “Will you commit that, if you are confirmed as Attorney General, you will recuse yourself from any investigation into whether President-elect Trump or any of his family, campaign staff, business associates or advisors had any communication with Russian officials or operatives during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign, or had any connection to, knowledge of, or involvement in Russian efforts to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election?” Sessions responded, “I am not aware of a basis to recuse myself from such investigations. However, if a specific matter arose where I believed my impartiality might reasonably be questioned, I would consult with Department ethics officials regarding the most appropriate way to proceed. As I made clear at my confirmation hearing, I will always be fair and work within the law and the established procedures of the Department.”

How he could not see that his own communications would be at issue is puzzling.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2017/03/02/why-jeff-s...
